Mayor Bill Foster: s public service announcement: Mayor Foster interrupted a mayoral forum to deliver an important message about the high percentage of auto thefts caused by people leaving their keys in the car. This announcement serves as a direct source of information regarding the claim.
Police Chief Chuck Harmon: s statement: Chief Harmon confirms the high percentage of auto thefts caused by keys left in cars. He provides specific data, stating that out of the 551 cars stolen so far that year, 460 had keys either in the ignition or elsewhere in the vehicle. This statement adds credibility to the claim.
Expert opinion from Frank Scafidi: Frank Scafidi, spokesman for the National Insurance Crime Bureau, comments on the high percentage of auto thefts in St. Petersburg. He acknowledges that the numbers might be a "high-water mark" in the country, indicating that the situation in the city is particularly severe. Scafidi's expertise in the field adds weight to the claim.
National Highway Traffic Safety Administ: The claim is supported by statistics from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which states that 40 to 50 percent of auto thefts nationwide are due to keys left in the car. This national data reinforces the authenticity of the claim.
